lesson.title: Welcome to Artificial Intelligence
lesson.summary: Welcome to the Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree program!

concepts.title: Welcome to the Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree Program

atoms.text: Errata: @1:30 AlphaGo uses [Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_tree_search) rather than Minimax search -- although the minimax principle still applies. Minimax and alpha-beta pruning were used in Deep Blue (the NegaScout variant) [see [pg 60](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/ad2c/1efffcd7c3b7106e507396bdaa5fe00fa597.pdf)], and continues to be used in several state-of-the-art modern chess programs like [Stockfish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockfish_%28chess%29#Features).

# Getting Support

There are several ways in which you will receive support during the program from Udacity's network of Mentors, as well as your fellow students.

Your in-classroom Mentor will be your guide through the program and will do the following:
  * Assist you with questions you pose in each project channel in Study Groups.
  * Guide you to supplementary resources when you get stuck.
  * Respond to any questions you have about the program.

## Knowledge
---

To ask questions and get answers from Udacity staff and your peers, we have the [Knowledge](https://knowledge.udacity.com/) platform. If you have ever used StackOverflow, this platform is similar. You can post new questions here, add answers or conversational comments, and **upvote** questions and answers. You can also **search** for existing answers and filter by Nanodegree program and project. Knowledge is accessible from the classroom as a lightbulb icon that you'll see at the bottom left of your navigation bar.

##  Study Groups

Using the Chat option, you will be able to get to know your fellow students, ask any questions you may have or answer other student's questions. All of the students in your Chat group are taking the same Nanodegree as you are, and will be familiar with your dilemmas.

In Udacity Study Groups, you'll have different rooms where you can talk to your fellow classmates, as well as Mentors for your class. 

Your in-classroom Mentors will be your guide through the program and will do the following:
  * Help you set learning goals.
  * Guide you to supplementary resources when you get stuck.
  * Respond to any questions you have about the program.

There are separate rooms for each project, as well as a room for general discussion called "My Classmates".

To join Study Groups, click on the blue chat icon in the left hand menu when you are in the classroom. Then, agree to the Terms of Service. Lastly, join the 'My Classmates' channel to introduce yourself and meet your classmates.

## Reviews

For each project you submit, you will receive detailed feedback from a project Reviewer. 

Sometimes, a reviewer might ask you to resubmit a project to meet specifications. In that case, an indication of needed changes will also be provided. Note that you can submit a project as many times as needed to pass.

atoms.caption: An example of the personalized feedback you'll get on your projects with Udacity.

atoms.text:
## Community Guidelines

Your experience in the Nanodegree program and community should be an engaging, fulfilling, and positive one. As such, we have outlined the following system for reporting behavior that does not live up to Udacity’s standards, so it can quickly be addressed by our staff. 

All reports of suspected violations to the [TOU](https://www.udacity.com/legal/terms-of-service), [Community Code of Conduct](https://www.udacity.com/legal/community-guidelines) or [Honor Code](https://www.udacity.com/legal/community-guidelines) should be submitted to report@udacity.com  and will be reviewed. If you witness or are experiencing any violations of our policies please get in touch with us. Below prohibited actions as set forth on our [Community Code of Conduct](https://www.udacity.com/legal/community-guidelines):

- **Harassment:** Inappropriate, harassing, abusive, discriminatory, derogatory or violent comments or conduct. 
- **Discrimination:** Offensive comments related to gender or gender identity, sexual orientation, race, ethnicity, religion, national origin, disability or disease
- **Distributing inappropriate content:** Use of sexual, violent, graphic, or derogatory images
- **Bullying:** Deliberate intimidation, threats of violence or violent language directed against another person
- **Sexual harassment:** Unwelcome sexual attention 
- **Defamation:** Obscene, fraudulent, indecent, or libelous acts that defame, abuse, harass, discriminate against or threaten others
- **Plagiarism:** will not cheat on any homework assignment, projects or exams for the Online Courses and, specifically, will not plagiarize materials created by others
- **Self-injury or Suicide:** We do not encourage community postings related to self-injury or suicide. If you or someone you know is exhibiting signs of self-injury or suicide, find help at the [Suicide Prevention Lifeline](https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/) in the U.S. and [Befrienders.org](https://www.befrienders.org/) globally. 

When a potential violation is brought to our attention, we will make every effort to investigate the case thoroughly and make a decision that is fair to all parties.

Thank you, 
The Udacity Team

# Weekly Lesson Plans
The classroom content is grouped by topic, but that structure doesn't provide the most clear indication of what content you should cover each week. The AIND program has a set of weekly lesson plans linked within each topic that you can use to plan ahead for your term, and help monitor your progress so that you stay on track to graduate. The links will appear with headings that follow the pattern in the lesson list: **Lesson Plan: Week N**

Note that you are free to work ahead of the lesson plans, and you are **not required** to keep up with the suggested pace. Remember, project deadlines are flexible but the term deadline is not. If you fall behind, you can use the context in the lesson plans to prioritize which lessons are most relevant to completing the projects before your term ends.


## Links to each week
The lesson plans for this program are embedded directly in the classroom. Use the links below to jump to a specific week.

- [Lesson Plan: Week 1](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd898/parts/75fe3a30-2531-4040-81e8-c4db62f32c0b/modules/2d1f0742-d727-4993-844b-2a390f9280a7/lessons/31f71698-b09c-44cd-a206-60836cca0e00/concepts/9bc0c8b0-5328-46db-8382-1014c4391c36)
- [Lesson Plan: Week 2](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd898/parts/2daa0bcc-325e-420e-a677-717f760ca6b7/modules/6a6811f6-5cec-4992-9b29-47b20661c1b8/lessons/f8def63a-dcb3-4af3-a9bc-27bca8a67996/concepts/709e3b45-918c-42fe-85e7-acab2d25f1a6)
- [Lesson Plan: Week 3](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd898/parts/842c5b09-edc1-4378-8c93-d37af6f57477/modules/b9fa4cfb-a42f-4996-a2db-33b88e20248a/lessons/91f98086-586e-4a1d-91f1-9454e05d0136/concepts/3a955131-bb9f-4bb7-8a60-0fbf298affe3)

- [Lesson Plan: Week 5](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd898/parts/408a79d4-7279-4f8d-bdfd-3cd04f2fb778/modules/1c5796bb-b34c-4781-b3e7-62017c5ce551/lessons/e6a4973b-e900-492c-bab3-056f11bb4a8c/concepts/f7ced64e-9b0b-46ba-bbc9-822899f0e617)

## References & Resources

This lesson provides a list of resources for topics you should know in order to get the most from the Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree program. **You are NOT required to review or complete all these resources before proceeding to the course content.** These resources are strictly provided as references that you may turn to if you find yourself blocked by unfamiliar content outside the scope of instruction in the Artificial Intelligence lessons.

The [Student Resources Page](https://sites.google.com/knowlabs.com/aind-student-resources/home) includes weekly schedules for each term to help you plan and keep pace, and useful information on the [Project Assistant](https://sites.google.com/knowlabs.com/aind-student-resources/project-assistant) tool used to submit projects.

---

## Python Programming
The Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree program requires intermediate Python programming skills, but prior intermediate-level programming experience in almost any language should be adequate to complete the projects. If Python is new, then it will help if you have prior experience in a C-style (C++, Java, Javascript, Python, etc.) language that supports object oriented programming.

### Required Skills
- Recognize and use variables
- Control program flow with conditional statements
- Looping (including list comprehensions & generator statements)
- Write, modify, and use functions
- Write, modify, & use classes/objects (including object attributes & methods)

### Resources
- [Udacity’s Intro to Python Course](https://www.udacity.com/course/introduction-to-python--ud1110)
- [Python Wiki: “Moving to Python from another language”](https://wiki.python.org/moin/MovingToPythonFromOtherLanguages)
- [Google’s Python for Developers course](https://developers.google.com/edu/python/)
- [Design of Computer Programs with Peter Norvig](https://www.udacity.com/course/design-of-computer-programs--cs212)
---

## Shell Programming
The Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree program uses a couple of tools that are most conveniently executed as shell scripts including [Git](https://git-scm.com/), and the [Udacity Project Assistant](https://project-assistant.udacity.com/faq). You should be able to launch a terminal (bash/cmd/powershell, etc., depending on your OS) and execute programs from the command line. (Specific instructions for each required tool are provided in the classroom.)

### Required Skills
- Git basics (cloning a repository)
- Use a shell terminal to execute programs like:
  - Python & conda (package manager)
  - Udacity Project Assistant CLI tool

### Resources
- [Udacity free course on Git](https://www.udacity.com/course/how-to-use-git-and-github--ud775)
- [Git documentation](https://git-scm.com/docs/gittutorial)
- [Bash (Linux & OS X)](https://www.gnu.org/doc/doc.html) or [Powershell (windows)](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/)

---

## Mathematics
The Artificial Intelligence Nanodegree program expects some familiarity with advanced mathematics including differential calculus, linear algebra, and discrete mathematics

### Required Topics
- Continuous functions & derivatives
- Linear algebra (vector spaces & operations)
- Elementary Graph Theory (definitions for nodes, edges, connectedness, etc.)
- Complexity Classes (big-O notation)
- Elementary Set Theory (definition of a set, etc.)
- Basic Logical Statements (truth tables, etc.)

### Resources
- [Udacity Linear Algebra Refresher Course](https://classroom.udacity.com/courses/ud953)
- Lessons 1, 3, and 6 of [Udacity’s Intro to Algorithms Class](https://www.udacity.com/course/intro-to-algorithms--cs215) (Social Network Magic Trick, Basic Graph Algorithms, and Hardness of Network Problems.)

# Lesson Plan: Week 1
---
Your focus this week should be on acclimating to the Udacity platform and completing the first project.

**Note:** Most of the reading assignments in this course are **optional**. The optional readings from the textbook Artificial Intelligence: a Modern Approach [here](http://aima.cs.berkeley.edu/)—often abbreviated throughout the course as "AIMA"—reinforce and expand the topics in the lectures. We will provide copies of any **required** reading material, however you will need to obtain your own copy of the textbook for the _optional_ readings. Prior versions of the book are available through the AIMA site through the link above, and current versions are available for rent or purchase online, or you can check with your library to see if they have access to a copy.

## Classroom
- Watch the introduction lessons (Welcome to AI, Intro to AI, Setting up Anaconda, Workspaces, & Solving Sudoku with AI)
 - The [References & Resources lesson](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd898/parts/75fe3a30-2531-4040-81e8-c4db62f32c0b/modules/2d1f0742-d727-4993-844b-2a390f9280a7/lessons/31f71698-b09c-44cd-a206-60836cca0e00/concepts/8ca51064-ce48-4ebd-9487-c92c7b0332bc) includes links for Python & Git (which may be useful for project 1)
- Follow the classroom instructions in Setting up Your Environment to install and configure Anaconda with all the packages and libraries required for the projects and classroom exercises.

- **Complete the first project: Solving Sudoku with AI**
 - You may refer to the AIMA textbook chapter 6.2 Constraint Propagation, and chapter 3.1-3.4 on Search (you will read these chapters more carefully in later weeks -- no need to read them in-depth now)

## Reading
- (_Optional_) Skim **AIMA Chapter 1 & 2** - these sections introduce some key terms that may be new and that will be used frequently throughout the program

## Announcements
- The course **refund deadline is the end of the first week** 1 (7 days after the term starts)
- The first project **Solving Sudoku with AI is due at the end of Week 1**
